Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation2: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, my stepmother’s voice echoing in my mind: “Family comes first, especially during our traditions.” Tonight was the annual family dinner, a ritual my stepfather’s side held sacred. I could feel their eyes on me, expecting me to join in, to show I belonged. My phone buzzed in my pocket—again. I knew it was from work. Our team lead had messaged earlier, stressing the urgency of confirming details for tomorrow’s meeting with an important partner. I was supposed to reply quickly, to show reliability as a colleague. But here, in this room, my stepfamily expected my full attention, no distractions, no phones at the table. My heart pounded as I weighed the phone in my hand under the tablecloth, torn between the warmth of family tradition and the cold urgency of my professional responsibility.
